currentDoc:
How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion,

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, American adults need to worry less about screen time and more about letting children sit alone on screens all day.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

American adults need to worry less about our own screen time and more about letting children sit alone on screens all day. We need to let them enjoy the company of their friends online, talk to them about the huge amount of bullying and meanness in the virtual world too. And we need to talk to them about staying safe in this virtual world. But we need to be reasonable. They need to balance screen time with spending face-to-face time, enjoying the outdoors, and actually parti

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

American adults need to worry less about our own screen time and more about letting children sit alone on screens all day. We need to let them enjoy the company of their friends online, talk to them about the huge amount of bullying and meanness in the virtual world too. And we need to talk to them about staying safe in this virtual world. But we need to be reasonable. They need to balance screen time with spending face-to-face time, enjoying the outdoors, and actually participating in activities,

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

American adults need to worry less about our own screen time and more about letting children sit alone on screens all day. We need to let them enjoy the company of their friends online, talk to them about the huge amount of bullying and meanness in the virtual world too. And we need to talk to them about staying safe in this virtual world. But we need to be reasonable. They need to balance screen time with spending face-to-face time, enjoying the outdoors, and actually participating in activities, instead of watching them. 
Wust how much screen time is too much screen time?
  t's all a matter of balance.

And we need to talk to them about staying safe in this virtual world. But we need to be reasonable. They need to balance screen time with spending face-to-face time, enjoying the outdoors, and actually participating in activities, instead of watching them. 
Wust how much screen time is too much screen time?
  t's all a matter of balance.
 It's not just the amount of time that matters, but also what you're doing with your device. Spending time on screens might be a problem if the child is using a device to escape from the things around them or if they are ignoring their family. Screens can make you feel more isolated from your surrounding. And when you're depressed, spending more time on screen might even make things worse. But screens can be useful, to learn new things,  t

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

American adults need to worry less about our own screen time and more about letting children sit alone on screens all day. We need to let them enjoy the company of their friends online, talk to them about the huge amount of bullying and meanness in the virtual world too. And we need to talk to them about staying safe in this virtual world. But we need to be reasonable. They need to balance screen time with spending face-to-face time, enjoying the outdoors, and actually participating in activities, instead of watching them. 
Wust how much screen time is too much screen time?
  t's all a matter of balance.
 It's not just the amount of time that matters, but also what you're doing with your device. Spending time on screens might be a problem if the child is using a device to escape from the things around them or if they are ignoring their family. Screens can make you feel more isolated from your surrounding. And when you're depressed, spending more time on screen might even make things worse. But screens can be useful, to learn new things,  talk with family and frei

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

American adults need to worry less about our own screen time and more about letting children sit alone on screens all day. We need to let them enjoy the company of their friends online, talk to them about the huge amount of bullying and meanness in the virtual world too. And we need to talk to them about staying safe in this virtual world. But we need to be reasonable. They need to balance screen time with spending face-to-face time, enjoying the outdoors, and actually participating in activities, instead of watching them.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

American adults need to worry less about our own screen time and more about letting children sit alone on screens all day. We need to let them enjoy the company of their friends online, talk to them about the huge amount of bullying and meanness in the virtual world too. And we need to talk to them about staying safe in this virtual world. But we need to be reasonable. They need to balance screen time with spending face-to-face time, enjoying the outdoors, and actually participating in activities, instead of watching them. 
Wust how much screen time is too much screen time?
  t's all a matter of balance.
 It's not just the amount of time that matters, but also what you're doing with your device. Spending time on screens might be a problem if the child is using a device to escape from the things around them or if they are ignoring their family. Screens can make you feel more isolated from your surrounding. And when you're depressed, spending more time on screen might even make things worse. But screen  can be useful, to learn new things,  talk with family and friends, and enjoy innocent entertainment. Once you have a good balance of activities around screen time, it isn't bad.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---
Computers and Pho
American adults need to worry less about our own screen time and more about letting children sit alone on screens all day. We need to let them enjoy the company of their friends online, talk to them about the huge amount of bullying and meanness in the virtual world too. And we need to talk to them about staying safe in this virtual world. But we need to be reasonable. They need to balance screen time with spending face-to-face time, enjoying the outdoors, and actually participating in activities, instead of watching them. 
Wust how much screen time is too much screen time?
  t's all a matter of balance.
 It's not just the amount of time that matters, but also what you're doing with your device. Spending time on screens might be a problem if the child is using a device to escape from the things around them or if they are ignoring their family. Screens can make you feel more isolated from your surrounding. And when you're depressed, spending more time on screen might even make things worse. 

Screen time can be useful, to learn new things,  talk with family and friends, and enjoy innocent entertainment. Once you have a good balance of activities around screen time, it isn't bad.

Screen time can be useful, to learn new things,  talk with family and friends, and enjoy innocent entertainment. Once you have a good balance of activities around screen time, it isn't bad.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---
Computers and phones are here to stay
American adults need to worry less about our own screen time and more about letting children sit alone on screens all day. We need to let them enjoy the company of their friends online, talk to them about the huge amount of bullying and meanness in the virtual world too. And we need to talk to them about staying safe in this virtual world. But we need to be reasonable. They need to balance screen time with spending face-to-face time, enjoying the outdoors, and actually participating in activities, instead of watching them. 
Wust how much screen time is too much screen time?
  t's all a matter of balance.
 It's not just the amount of time that matters, but also what you're doing with your device. Spending time on screens might be a problem if the child is using a device to escape from the things around them or if they are ignoring their family. We need to let them enjoy the company of their friends online, talk to them about the huge amount of bullying and meanness in the virtual world too. And we need to talk to them about staying safe in this virtual world. But we need to be reasonable. They need to balance screen time with spending face-to-face time, enjoying the outdoors, and actually participating in activities, instead of watching them. 
Wust how much screen time is too much screen time?
  t's all a matter of balance.
 It's not just the amount of time that matters, but also what you're doing with your device. Spending time on screens might be a problem if the child is using a device to escape from the things around them or if they are ignoring their family. Screens can make you feel more isolated from your surrounding. And when you're depressed, spending more time on screen might even make things worse. 

Screen time can be useful, to learn new things,  talk with family and friends, and enjoy innocent entertainment. Once you have a good balance of activities around screen time, it isn't bad.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

  t's all a matter of balance.
 It's not just the amount of time that matters, but also what you're doing with your device. Spending time on screens might be a problem if the child is using a device to escape from the things around them or if they are ignoring their family. Screens can make you feel more isolated from your surrounding. And when you're depressed, spending more time on screen might even make things worse. 

Screen time can be useful, to learn new things,  talk with family and friends, and enjoy innocent entertainment. Once you have a good balance of activities around screen time, it isn't bad.

Wust how much screen time is too much screen time?
  t's all a matter of balance.
 It's not just the amount of time that matters, but also what you're doing with your device. Spending time on screens might be a problem if the child is using a device to escape from the things around them or if they are ignoring their family. Screens can make you feel more isolated from your surrounding. And when you're depressed, spending more time on screen might even make things worse. 

Screen time can be useful, to learn new things,  talk with family and friends, and enjoy innocent entertainment. Once you have a good balance of activities around screen time, it isn't bad.

We need to let them enjoy the company of their friends online, talk to them about the huge amount of bullying and meanness in the virtual world too. And we need to talk to them about staying safe in this virtual world. But we need to be reasonable. They need to balance screen time with spending face-to-face time, enjoying the outdoors, and actually participating in activities, instead of watching them. 
Wust how much screen time is too much screen time?
  t's all a matter of balance.
 It's not just the amount of time that matters, but also what you're doing with your device. Spending time on screens might be a problem if the child is using a device to escape from the things around them or if they are ignoring their family. Screens can make you feel more isolated from your surrounding. And when you're depressed, spending more time on screen might even make things worse. 

Screen time can be useful, to learn new things,  talk with family and friends, and enjoy innocent entertainment. Once you have a good balance of activities around screen time, it isn't bad.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

Screen time can be useful, to learn new things,  talk with family and friends, and enjoy innocent entertainment. Once you have a good balance of activities around screen time, it isn't bad.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---
Computers and phones are here to stay. Many jobs will require emailing, talking or texting, entering data, observin multiple times a day
American adults need to worry less about our own screen time and more about letting children sit alone on screens all day. We need to let them enjoy the company of their friends online, talk to them about the huge amount of bullying and meanness in the virtual world too. And we need to talk to them about staying safe in this virtual world. But we need to be reasonable. They need to balance screen time with spending face-to-face time, enjoying the outdoors, and actually participating in activities, instead of watching them. 
Wust how much screen time is too much screen time?
  t's all a matter of balance.
 It's not just the amount of time that matters, but also what you're doing with your device. Computers and phones are here to stay. Many jobs will require emailing, talking or texting, entering data, observing charts and screens multiple times a day
American adults need to worry less about our own screen time and more about letting children sit alone on screens all day. We need to let them enjoy the company of their friends online, talk to them about the huge amount of bullying and meanness in the virtual world too. And we need to talk to them about staying safe in this virtual world. But we need to be reasonable. They need to balance screen time with spending face-to-face time, enjoying the outdoors, and actually participating in activities, instead of watching them. 
Wust how much screen time is too much screen time?
  t's all a matter of balance.
 It's not just the amount of time that matters, but also what you're doing with your device. Spending time on screens might be a problem if the child is using a device to escape from the things around them or if they are ignoring their family. Screens can make you feel more isolated from your surrounding. And when you're depressed, spending more time on screen might even make things worse. 

Screen time can be useful, to learn new things,  talk with family and friends, and enjoy innocent entertainment. Once you have a good balance of activities around screen time, it isn't bad.

We need to let them enjoy the company of their friends online, talk to them about the huge amount of bullying and meanness in the virtual world too. And we need to talk to them about staying safe in this virtual world. But we need to be reasonable. They need to balance screen time with spending face-to-face time, enjoying the outdoors, and actually participating in activities, instead of watching them. 
Wust how much screen time is too much screen time?
  t's all a matter of balance.
 It's not just the amount of time that matters, but also what you're doing with your device. Spending time on screens might be a problem if the child is using a device to escape from the things around them or if they are ignoring their family. Screens can make you feel more isolated from your surrounding. And when you're depressed, spending more time on screen might even make things worse. 

Screen time can be useful, to learn new things,  talk with family and friends, and enjoy innocent entertainment. Once you have a good balance of activities around screen time, it isn't bad.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

Computers and phones are here to stay. Many jobs will require emailing, talking or texting, entering data, observing charts and screens multiple times a day. It is an unescapable part of 
American adults need to worry less about our own screen time and more about letting children sit alone on screens all day. We need to let them enjoy the company of their friends online, talk to them about the huge amount of bullying and meanness in the virtual world too. And we need to talk to them about staying safe in this virtual world. But we need to be reasonable. They need to balance screen time with spending face-to-face time, enjoying the outdoors, and actually participating in activities, instead of watching them. 
Wust how much screen time is too much screen time?
  t's all a matter of balance.
 It's not just the amount of time that matters, but also what you're doing with your device. Spending time on screens might be a problem if the child is using a device to escape from the things around them or if they are ignoring their family. Screens can make you feel more isolated from your surrounding. And when you're depressed, spending more time on screen might even make things worse. 

Screen time can be useful, to learn new things,  talk with family and friends, and enjoy innocent entertainment. Once you have a good balance of activities around screen time, it isn't bad.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---
Computers and phones are here to stay. Many jobs will require emailing, talking or texting, entering data, observing charts and screens multiple times a day. It is an unescapable part of adult life. 

American adults need to worry less about our own screen time and more about letting children sit alone on screens all day. We need to let them enjoy the company of their friends online, talk to them about the huge amount of bullying and meanness in the virtual world too. And we need to talk to them about staying safe in this virtual world. But we need to be reasonable. They need to balance screen time with spending face-to-face time, enjoying the outdoors, and actually participating in activities, instead of watching them. 
Wust how much screen time is too much screen time?

Screen time can be useful, to learn new things,  talk with family and friends, and enjoy innocent entertainment. Once you have a good balance of activities around screen time, it isn't bad. There is a lot of evidence that video games improve hand-eye coordination and sharpen the reaction time.

American adults need to worry less about our own screen time and more about letting children sit alone on screens all day. We need to let them enjoy the company of their friends online, talk to them about the huge amount of bullying and meanness in the virtual world too. And we need to talk to them about staying safe in this virtual world. But we need to be reasonable. They need to balance screen time with spending face-to-face time, enjoying the outdoors, and actually participating in activities, instead of watching them. 
Wust how much screen time is too much screen time?
  t's all a matter of balance.
 It's not just the amount of time that matters, but also what you're doing with your device. Spending time on screens might be a problem if the child is using a device to escape from the things around them or if they are ignoring their family. Screens can make you feel more isolated from your surrounding. And when you're depressed, spending more time on screen might even make things worse. 

Screen time can be useful, to learn new things,  talk with family and friends, and enjoy innocent entertainment. Once you have a good balance of activities around screen time, it isn't bad. There is a lot of evidence that video games improve hand-eye coordination and sharpen the reaction time. 

We should balance our scr

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

Screens can make you feel more isolated from your surrounding. And when you're depressed, spending more time on screen might even make things worse. 

Screen time can be useful, to learn new things,  talk with family and friends, and enjoy innocent entertainment. Once you have a good balance of activities around screen time, it isn't bad. There is a lot of evidence that video games improve hand-eye coordination and sharpen the reaction time.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---
Computers and phones are here to stay. Many jobs will require emailing, talking or texting, entering data, observing charts and screens multiple times a day. It is an unescapable part of adult life. 

American adults need to worry less about our own screen time and more about letting children sit alone on screens all day. We need to let them enjoy the company of their friends online, talk to them about the huge amount of bullying and meanness in the virtual world too. And we need to talk to them about staying safe in this virtual world. But we need to be reasonable. They need to balance screen time with spending face-to-face time, enjoying the outdoors, and actually participating in activities, instead of watching them. 
Wust how much screen time is too much screen time?
  t's all a matter of balance.

Spending time on screens might be a problem if the child is using a device to escape from the things around them or if they are ignoring their family. Screen time can be useful, to learn new things,  talk with family and friends, and enjoy innocent entertainment. Once you have a good balance of activities around screen time, it isn't bad. There is a lot of evidence that video games improve hand-eye coordination and sharpen the reaction time.

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---
Computers and phones are here to stay. Many jobs will require emailing, talking or texting, entering data, observing charts and screens multiple times a day. It is an unescapable part of adult life. 

American adults need to worry less about our own screen time and more about letting children sit alone on screens all day. We need to let them enjoy the company of their friends online, talk to them about the huge amount of bullying and meanness in the virtual world too. And we need to talk to them about staying safe in this virtual world. But we need to be reasonable. They need to balance screen time with spending face-to-face time, enjoying the outdoors, and actually participating in activities, instead of watching them. 
Wust how much screen time is too much screen time?
  t's all a matter of balance.
 It's not just the amount of time that matters, but also what you're doing with your device. Spending time on screens might be a problem if the child is using a device to escape from the things around them or if they are ignoring their family. Screens can make you feel more isolated from your surrounding. And when you're depressed, spending more time on screen might even make things worse. 

Screen time can be useful, to learn new things,  talk with family and friends, and enjoy innocent entertainment. Once you have a good balance of activities around screen time, it isn't bad. There is a lot of evidence that video games improve hand-eye coordination and sharpen the reaction time. 

We should balance our screen time with set activities. Every hour, w

Computers and phones are here to stay. Many jobs will require emailing, talking or texting, entering data, observing charts and screens multiple times a day. It is an unescapable part of adult life. 

American adults need to worry less about our own screen time and more about letting children sit alone on screens all day. We need to let them enjoy the company of their friends online, talk to them about the huge amount of bullying and meanness in the virtual world too. And we need to talk to them about staying safe in this virtual world. But we need to be reasonable. They need to balance screen time with spending face-to-face time, enjoying the outdoors, and actually participating in activities, instead of watching them. 
Wust how much screen time is too much screen time?
  t's all a matter of balance.
 It's not just the amount of time that matters, but also what you're doing with your device. Spending time on screens might be a problem if the child is using a device to escape from the things around them or if they are ignoring their family. Screens can make you feel more isolated from your surrounding. And when you're depressed, spending more time on screen might even make things worse. 

Screen time can be useful, to learn new things,  talk with family and friends, and enjoy innocent entertainment. Once you have a good balance of activities around screen time, it isn't bad. There is a lot of evidence that video games improve hand-eye coordination and sharpen the reaction time. 

We should balance our screen time with set activities. Every hour, take a wal

Computers and phones are here to stay. Many jobs will require emailing, talking or texting, entering data, observing charts and screens multiple times a day. It is an unescapable part of adult life. 

American adults need to worry less about our own screen time and more about letting children sit alone on screens all day. We need to let them enjoy the company of their friends online, talk to them about the huge amount of bullying and meanness in the virtual world too. And we need to talk to them about staying safe in this virtual world. But we need to be reasonable. They need to balance screen time with spending face-to-face time, enjoying the outdoors, and actually participating in activities, instead of watching them. 
Wust how much screen time is too much screen time?
  t's all a matter of balance.
 It's not just the amount of time that matters, but also what you're doing with your device. Spending time on screens might be a problem if the child is using a device to escape from the things around them or if they are ignoring their family. Screens can make you feel more isolated from your surrounding. And when you're depressed, spending more time on screen might even make things worse. 

Screen time can be useful, to learn new things,  talk with family and friends, and enjoy innocent entertainment. Once you have a good balance of activities around screen time, it isn't bad. There is a lot of evidence that video games improve hand-eye coordination and sharpen the reaction time. 

We should balance our screen time with set activities. Every hour, take a walk outside for 10 min.

 It's not just the amount of time that matters, but also what you're doing with your device. Spending time on screens might be a problem if the child is using a device to escape from the things around them or if they are ignoring their family. Screens can make you feel more isolated from your surrounding. And when you're depressed, spending more time on screen might even make things worse. 

Screen time can be useful, to learn new things,  talk with family and friends, and enjoy innocent entertainment. Once you have a good balance of activities around screen time, it isn't bad. There is a lot of evidence that video games improve hand-eye coordination and sharpen the reaction time. 

We should balance our screen time with set activities. Every hour, take a walk outside for 10 min. Play with your dog. Hug your loved ones. Vacuum. Wash the dishes. T

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---
Computers and phones are here to stay. Many jobs will require emailing, talking or texting, entering data, observing charts and screens multiple times a day. It is an unescapable part of adult life. 

American adults need to worry less about our own screen time and more about letting children sit alone on screens all day. We need to let them enjoy the company of their friends online, talk to them about the huge amount of bullying and meanness in the virtual world too. And we need to talk to them about staying safe in this virtual world. But we need to be reasonable. They need to balance screen time with spending face-to-face time, enjoying the outdoors, and actually participating in activities, instead of watching them. 
Wust how much screen time is too much screen time?
  t's all a matter of balance.
 It's not just the amount of time that matters, but also what you're doing with your device. Spending time on screens might be a problem if the child is using a device to escape from the things around them or if they are ignoring their family. Screens can make you feel more isolated from your surrounding. And when you're depressed, spending more time on screen might even make things worse. 

Screen time can be useful, to learn new things,  talk with family and friends, and enjoy innocent entertainment. Once you have a good balance of activities around screen time, it isn't bad. There is a lot of evidence that video games improve hand-eye coordination and sharpen the reaction time. 

We should balance our screen time with set activities. Every hour, take a walk outside for 10 min. Play with your dog. Hug your loved ones. Vacuum. Wash the dishes.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---
Computers and phones are here to stay. Many jobs will require emailing, talking or texting, entering data, observing charts and screens multiple times a day. It is an unescapable part of adult life. 

American adults need to worry less about our own screen time and more about letting children sit alone on screens all day. We need to let them enjoy the company of their friends online, talk to them about the huge amount of bullying and meanness in the virtual world too. And we need to talk to them about staying safe in this virtual world. But we need to be reasonable. They need to balance screen time with spending face-to-face time, enjoying the outdoors, and actually participating in activities, instead of watching them. 
Wust how much screen time is too much screen time?
  t's all a matter of balance.
 It's not just the amount of time that matters, but also what you're doing with your device. How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---
Computers and phones are here to stay. Many jobs will require emailing, talking or texting, entering data, observing charts and screens multiple times a day. It is an unescapable part of adult life. 

American adults need to worry less about our own screen time and more about letting children sit alone on screens all day. We need to let them enjoy the company of their friends online, talk to them about the huge amount of bullying and meanness in the virtual world too. And we need to talk to them about staying safe in this virtual world. But we need to be reasonable. They need to balance screen time with spending face-to-face time, enjoying the outdoors, and actually participating in activities, instead of watching them.

We need to let them enjoy the company of their friends online, talk to them about the huge amount of bullying and meanness in the virtual world too. And we need to talk to them about staying safe in this virtual world. But we need to be reasonable. They need to balance screen time with spending face-to-face time, enjoying the outdoors, and actually participating in activities, instead of watching them. 
Wust how much screen time is too much screen time?
  t's all a matter of balance.
 It's not just the amount of time that matters, but also what you're doing with your device. Spending time on screens might be a problem if the child is using a device to escape from the things around them or if they are ignoring their family. Screens can make you feel more isolated from your surrounding. And when you're depressed, spending more time on screen might even make things worse. 

Screen time can be useful, to learn new things,  talk with family and friends, and enjoy innocent entertainment. Once you have a good balance of activities around screen time, it isn't bad. There is a lot of evidence that video games improve hand-eye coordination and sharpen the reaction time. 

We should balance our screen time with set activities. Every hour, take a walk outside for 10 min. Play with your dog. Hug your loved ones. Vacuum. Wash the dishes. Have the kids help us, and in doing so, we'll set an example of

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

American adults need to worry less about our own screen time and more about letting children sit alone on screens all day. We need to let them enjoy the company of their friends online, talk to them about the huge amount of bullying and meanness in the virtual world too. And we need to talk to them about staying safe in this virtual world. But we need to be reasonable. They need to balance screen time with spending face-to-face time, enjoying the outdoors, and actually participating in activities, instead of watching them. 
Wust how much screen time is too much screen time?
  t's all a matter of balance.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---
Computers and phones are here to stay. Many jobs will require emailing, talking or texting, entering data, observing charts and screens multiple times a day. It is an unescapable part of adult life. 

American adults need to worry less about our own screen time and more about letting children sit alone on screens all day. We need to let them enjoy the company of their friends online, talk to them about the huge amount of bullying and meanness in the virtual world too. And we need to talk to them about staying safe in this virtual world. But we need to be reasonable. They need to balance screen time with spending face-to-face time, enjoying the outdoors, and actually participating in activities, instead of watching them. 
Wust how much screen time is too much screen time?
  t's all a matter of balance.
 It's not just the amount of time that matters, but also what you're doing with your device. Spending time on screens might be a problem if the child is using a device to escape from the things around them or if they are ignoring their family. Screens can make you feel more isolated from your surrounding. And when you're depressed, spending more time on screen might even make things worse. 

Screen time can be useful, to learn new things,  talk with family and friends, and enjoy innocent entertainment. Once you have a good balance of activities around screen time, it isn't bad. There is a lot of evidence that video games improve hand-eye coordination and sharpen the reaction time. 

We should balance our screen time with set activities. Every hour, take a walk outside for 10 min. Play with your dog. Hug your loved ones. Vacuum. Wash the dishes. Have the kids help us, and in doing so, we'll set an example of balance they can use for the rest of thei

We need to let them enjoy the company of their friends online, talk to them about the huge amount of bullying and meanness in the virtual world too. And we need to talk to them about staying safe in this virtual world. But we need to be reasonable. They need to balance screen time with spending face-to-face time, enjoying the outdoors, and actually participating in activities, instead of watching them. 
Wust how much screen time is too much screen time?
  t's all a matter of balance.
 It's not just the amount of time that matters, but also what you're doing with your device. Spending time on screens might be a problem if the child is using a device to escape from the things around them or if they are ignoring their family. Screens can make you feel more isolated from your surrounding. And when you're depressed, spending more time on screen might even make things worse. 

Screen time can be useful, to learn new things,  talk with family and friends, and enjoy innocent entertainment. Once you have a good balance of activities around screen time, it isn't bad. There is a lot of evidence that video games improve hand-eye coordination and sharpen the reaction time. 

We should balance our screen time with set activities. Every hour, take a walk outside for 10 min. Play with your dog. Hug your loved ones. Vacuum. Wash the dishes. Have the kids help us, and in doing so, we'll set an example of balance they can use for the rest of their lives. 

Screens ar

We need to let them enjoy the company of their friends online, talk to them about the huge amount of bullying and meanness in the virtual world too. And we need to talk to them about staying safe in this virtual world. But we need to be reasonable. They need to balance screen time with spending face-to-face time, enjoying the outdoors, and actually participating in activities, instead of watching them. 
Wust how much screen time is too much screen time?
  t's all a matter of balance.
 It's not just the amount of time that matters, but also what you're doing with your device. Spending time on screens might be a problem if the child is using a device to escape from the things around them or if they are ignoring their family. Screens can make you feel more isolated from your surrounding. And when you're depressed, spending more time on screen might even make things worse. 

Screen time can be useful, to learn new things,  talk with family and friends, and enjoy innocent entertainment. Once you have a good balance of activities around screen time, it isn't bad. There is a lot of evidence that video games improve hand-eye coordination and sharpen the reaction time. 

We should balance our screen time with set activities. Every hour, take a walk outside for 10 min. Play with your dog. Hug your loved ones. Vacuum. Wash the dishes. Have the kids help us, and in doing so, we'll set an example of balance they can use for the rest of their lives. 

Screens are here to st

We need to let them enjoy the company of their friends online, talk to them about the huge amount of bullying and meanness in the virtual world too. And we need to talk to them about staying safe in this virtual world. But we need to be reasonable. They need to balance screen time with spending face-to-face time, enjoying the outdoors, and actually participating in activities, instead of watching them. 
Wust how much screen time is too much screen time?
  t's all a matter of balance.
 It's not just the amount of time that matters, but also what you're doing with your device. Spending time on screens might be a problem if the child is using a device to escape from the things around them or if they are ignoring their family. Screens can make you feel more isolated from your surrounding. And when you're depressed, spending more time on screen might even make things worse. 

Screen time can be useful, to learn new things,  talk with family and friends, and enjoy innocent entertainment. Once you have a good balance of activities around screen time, it isn't bad. There is a lot of evidence that video games improve hand-eye coordination and sharpen the reaction time. 

We should balance our screen time with set activities. Every hour, take a walk outside for 10 min. Play with your dog. Hug your loved ones. Vacuum. Wash the dishes. Have the kids help us, and in doing so, we'll set an example of balance they can use for the rest of their lives.

American adults need to worry less about our own screen time and more about letting children sit alone on screens all day. We need to let them enjoy the company of their friends online, talk to them about the huge amount of bullying and meanness in the virtual world too. And we need to talk to them about staying safe in this virtual world. But we need to be reasonable. They need to balance screen time with spending face-to-face time, enjoying the outdoors, and actually participating in activities, instead of watching them. 
Wust how much screen time is too much screen time?
  t's all a matter of balance.
 It's not just the amount of time that matters, but also what you're doing with your device. Spending time on screens might be a problem if the child is using a device to escape from the things around them or if they are ignoring their family. Screens can make you feel more isolated from your surrounding. And when you're depressed, spending more time on screen might even make things worse. 

Screen time can be useful, to learn new things,  talk with family and friends, and enjoy innocent entertainment. Once you have a good balance of activities around screen time, it isn't bad. There is a lot of evidence that video games improve hand-eye coordination and sharpen the reaction time. 

We should balance our screen time with set activities. Every hour, take a walk outside for 10 min. Play with your dog. Hug your loved ones. Vacuum. Wash the dishes. Have the kids help us, and in doing so, we'll set an example of balance they can use for the rest of their lives.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---
Computers and phones are here to stay. Many jobs will require emailing, talking or texting, entering data, observing charts and screens multiple times a day. It is an unescapable part of adult life. 

American adults need to worry less about our own screen time and more about letting children sit alone on screens all day. We need to let them enjoy the company of their friends online, talk to them about the huge amount of bullying and meanness in the virtual world too. And we need to talk to them about staying safe in this virtual world. But we need to be reasonable. They need to balance screen time with spending face-to-face time, enjoying the outdoors, and actually participating in activities, instead of watching them. 
Wust how much screen time is too much screen time?
  t's all a matter of balance.
 It's not just the amount of time that matters, but also what you're doing with your device. Spending time on screens might be a problem if the child is using a device to escape from the things around them or if they are ignoring their family. Screens can make you feel more isolated from your surrounding. And when you're depressed, spending more time on screen might even make things worse. 

Screen time can be useful, to learn new things,  talk with family and friends, and enjoy innocent entertainment. Once you have a good balance of activities around screen time, it isn't bad. There is a lot of evidence that video games improve hand-eye coordination and sharpen the reaction time. 

We should balance our screen time with set activities. Every hour, take a walk outside for 10 min. Play with your dog. Hug your loved ones. Vacuum. Wash the dishes. Have the kids help us, and in doing so, we'll set an example of balance they can use for the rest of their lives. 

Screens are going to be a part of their life. We just need to t

 It's not just the amount of time that matters, but also what you're doing with your device. Spending time on screens might be a problem if the child is using a device to escape from the things around them or if they are ignoring their family. Screens can make you feel more isolated from your surrounding. And when you're depressed, spending more time on screen might even make things worse. 

Screen time can be useful, to learn new things,  talk with family and friends, and enjoy innocent entertainment. Once you have a good balance of activities around screen time, it isn't bad. There is a lot of evidence that video games improve hand-eye coordination and sharpen the reaction time. 

We should balance our screen time with set activities. Every hour, take a walk outside for 10 min. Play with your dog. Hug your loved ones. Vacuum. Wash the dishes. Have the kids help us, and in doing so, we'll set an example of balance they can use for the rest of their lives. 

Screens are going to be a part of their life. We just need to teach them how to ba

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---
Computers and phones are here to stay. Many jobs will require emailing, talking or texting, entering data, observing charts and screens multiple times a day. It is an unescapable part of adult life. 

American adults need to worry less about our own screen time and more about letting children sit alone on screens all day. We need to let them enjoy the company of their friends online, talk to them about the huge amount of bullying and meanness in the virtual world too. And we need to talk to them about staying safe in this virtual world. But we need to be reasonable. They need to balance screen time with spending face-to-face time, enjoying the outdoors, and actually participating in activities, instead of watching them.

We should balance our screen time with set activities. Every hour, take a walk outside for 10 min. Play with your dog. Hug your loved ones. Vacuum. Wash the dishes. Have the kids help us, and in doing so, we'll set an example of balance they can use for the rest of their lives.

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---
Computers and phones are here to stay. Many jobs will require emailing, talking or texting, entering data, observing charts and screens multiple times a day. It is an unescapable part of adult life. 

American adults need to worry less about our own screen time and more about letting children sit alone on screens all day. We need to let them enjoy the company of their friends online, talk to them about the huge amount of bullying and meanness in the virtual world too. And we need to talk to them about staying safe in this virtual world. But we need to be reasonable. They need to balance screen time with spending face-to-face time, enjoying the outdoors, and actually participating in activities, instead of watching them. 
Wust how much screen time is too much screen time?
  t's all a matter of balance.
 It's not just the amount of time that matters, but also what you're doing with your device. Spending time on screens might be a problem if the child is using a device to escape from the things around them or if they are ignoring their family. Screens can make you feel more isolated from your surrounding. And when you're depressed, spending more time on screen might even make things worse. 

Screen time can be useful, to learn new things,  talk with family and friends, and enjoy innocent entertainment. Once you have a good balance of activities around screen time, it isn't bad. There is a lot of evidence that video games improve hand-eye coordination and sharpen the reaction time. 

We should balance our screen time with set activities. Every hour, take a walk outside for 10 min. Play with your dog. Hug your loved ones. Vacuum. Wash the dishes. Have the kids help us, and in doing so, we'll set an example of balance they can use for the rest of their lives. 

Screens are going to be a part of their life. We just need to teach them how to balance it with oth
